name: Assyrian Genocide (Seyfo)
description: The Ottoman Empire's massacres of Assyrian Christians during World War I, concurrent with the Armenian Genocide. Assyrians faced mass killings, forced marches, and destruction of their ancient communities in southeastern Anatolia and northwestern Iran.

mortality.note: Called 'Seyfo' (sword) by Assyrians. Occurred alongside Armenian and Greek genocides. Estimates range from 150,000 to 750,000.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Simultaneous with Armenian and Greek genocides. Same methods: massacres, deportations, starvation.
rationales.profit: Land and property seizure in ancestral Assyrian territories.
rationales.ideology: Christian minorities targeted in Ottoman Muslim nationalist project.
rationales.complicity: Kurdish tribes participated in massacres. Least recognized of the three genocides.

analysis.pattern_note: Often overlooked alongside Armenian Genocide. Part of Ottoman campaign to create homogeneous Turkish state. Destroyed ancient Assyrian presence in southeastern Anatolia. Less internationally recognized than Armenian Genocide.
analysis.root_causes: Ottoman collapse, religious nationalism, WWI opportunity
